did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.unittitle: Tom Rankin photographs and papers 1980-2013 and undated
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Documentary photographer, filmmaker, folklorist, professor of art and documentary studies, and former director of the Center for Documentary Studies at Duke University.

The photographic work of Tom Rankin in this collection dates from 1980 to 2008, and consists of black-and-white gelatin silver and chromogenic color photographs documenting the American South, particularly religious sites, rituals, and communities in the Mississippi Delta region, but also individuals and landscapes from other locations in the South. Images often feature churches and cemeteries. One body of photographs features a series of portraits of Mississippi writer Larry Brown. Finished prints measure 11x14 and 16x20 inches, with some housed in mats. Along with the finished large-format prints, there are also 8x10 inch black-and-white matted contact prints. There is also a digital audio recording of a talk by Rankin at the exhibit opening of his work, Near the Cross: Photographs from the Mississippi Delta. A large addition to the collection consists of manuscript materials and two film reels deriving from Rankin's career and art practice, and dates from approximately 1980 to 2013. Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. However, publication and commercial use requires the permission of the photographer.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. There may be a 48-hour delay in obtaining these materials.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Tom Rankin Photographs and Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Tom Rankin photographs and papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift and purchase from 2007 to 2013.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Rubenstein Library staff, Dec. 2008
Encoded by Paula Jeannet Mangiafico, Matthew Warren, April 2014
Descriptive sources and standards used to create this inventory: DACS, EAD, NCEAD guidelines, and local Style Guide.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Tom Rankin served as the Director of the Center for Documentary Studies at Duke University for three consecutive five-year terms until 2013, and is a Professor of the Practice in the Arts at Duke University. A documentary photographer, filmmaker, writer, editor, and folklorist, he has been documenting and interpreting American culture, particularly in the South, for nearly twenty years. His photographic work has been published and widely exhibited. His most long-standing work has been to reveal through the documentary arts the culture and society of the Mississippi Delta region, where he has also served as a faculty member of Delta State University and the University of Mississippi. He has returned many times since the 1980s to photograph the landscapes and people of the Mississippi Delta, most recently in 2011 after the great floods of that year. His books include Sacred Space: Photographs from the Mississippi Delta (1993), which received the Mississippi Institute of Arts and Letters Award for Photography, 'Deaf Maggie Lee Sayre': Photographs of a River Life(1995), Faulkner's World: The Photographs of Martin J. Dain (1997), and Local Heroes Changing America: Indivisible (2000). He received an MFA from Georgia State University and an MA from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. American Photo Magazine named Tom Rankin as one of the 100 Most Important People in Photography, May, 2005.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The photographic work of Tom Rankin in this collection dates from 1980 to 2008, and consists of black-and-white gelatin silver and chromogenic color photographs from Rankin's work documenting the American South, particularly religious sites, rituals, and communities in the Mississippi Delta region, but also individuals and landscapes from other locations in the South. Images often feature churches and cemeteries. One body of photographs features a series of portraits of Mississippi writer Larry Brown. Finished prints measure 11x14 and 16x20 inches, with some housed in mats. Along with the finished large-format prints, there are also 8x10 inch black-and-white matted contact prints. All titles are original as designated by the photographer.

Supporting materials include a digital audio recording of a talk by Rankin at the exhibit opening of his work, Near the Cross: Photographs from the Mississippi Delta. A selection of Rankin's photographs was published in Sacred Space: Photographs from the Mississippi Delta, 1993. All titles are original as designated by the photographer. Some dates refer to printing dates rather than the date image was taken. An addition to the collection (2013-0114) (13,500 items, 22.5 lin. ft.) consists of manuscript materials related to Tom Rankin's career and art practice, including book publications and book dummies. Also includes two film reels.
Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual materials are closed to use. Use of these materials may require production of listening or viewing copies. Please contact a reference archivist before coming to use this collection.

arrangement.head: Collection Arrangement
arrangement.p: The photographic materials are arranged alphabetically by the title of the body of work: Larry Brown; Near the Cross: Mississippi Delta; Portraits of the American South; and Sacred Space. These are followed by Other Work, and Other Materials. Within project series, prints are in order as received from the photographer. The papers are currently unprocessed.

controlaccess.head: Subject Headings
controlaccess.p: These are searchable subject entries for this collection. Performing a search on these subjects in the Duke University Libraries online catalog will bring up other related research materials.

item.corpname: Duke University. Center for Documentary Studies

did.unittitle: Larry Brown, 1993-1996 and undated

scopecontent.p: Black-and-white gelatin silver and digital or chromogenic (C print) color portraits of Mississippi writer Larry Brown with his family and friends in Mississippi. Prints vary in size from 11x14" to 16x10" and are signed by the photographer. Arranged in original order as received.

Near the Cross: Mississippi Delta, late 1980s-early 1990s

scopecontent.p: Black-and-white gelatin silver prints document and reflect on spiritual and religious practices in the Mississippi Delta region of the Southern United States. Dominant subjects include churches, individuals associated with the churches, cemetery sites, and baptisms. All prints measure 11x14 inches. Arranged in original order as received. All titles are original.

Portraits of The American South, late 1990s-early 1990s

scopecontent.p: Images of individuals, cemeteries, businesses, and landscapes taken by Rankin in various Southern states, including Alabama, Georgia, Mississippi, and Virginia. Includes vintage chromogenic prints and black-and-white gelatin silver prints, ranging in size from 11x14 inches to 16x20 inches, with some black-and-white prints in mats. Some prints are signed by the photographer. Arranged in original order as received. All titles are original.

did.unittitle: Sacred Space, 1993

scopecontent.p: This body of work comprises 11x14 inches black-and-white gelatin silver prints, some in 16x20 inches mats; 16x20 inches gelatin silver prints in 20x24" mats; vintage 16x20 inches chromogenic color prints; and 8x10" black-and-white contact prints in 11x14 inches mats. Many prints are signed by the photographer. All locations are in Mississippi. Arranged in original order as received. All titles are original.

did.unittitle: Other Photographic Work Series, undated

scopecontent.p: Series houses prints that do not form part of other established bodies of photographic work in the collection. Original title supplied by photographer.

did.unittitle: Author Tim McLaurin at home with George, Hillsborough, North Carolina, undated
Manuscripts and Recordings Series, circa 1980-2013

scopecontent.p: Professional papers, including correspondence, writings, teaching materials, and other documents, stemming from Tom Rankin's long career in teaching and documentary arts, and serving as Director of the Center for Documentary Studies at Duke University. Includes a digital audio recording of his opening talk on February 27, 2008 at the Duke University Libraries exhibit of his work, Near the Cross: Photographs from the Mississippi Delta. This file has been mounted on the library server and is also available online through the Duke Libraries digital exhibits website. The papers have been given basic processing.

accessrestrict.p: [Original audiovisual materials are closed to use. Use of these materials may require production of listening or viewing copies. Please contact a reference archivist before coming to use this collection.]

did.unittitle: Papers and recordings, circa 1980-2013
